learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate foundation knowledge relating to the standards of professional speech pathology practice, ethics, reflective practice and life-long learning (SPA PS 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 2.1, 2.2, 2.3, 2.5, 2.6 and 3.1)

Describe and apply the principles of person- and family-centred care, evidence-based practice, inter-professional practice and the International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (2001) to speech pathology practice (SPA PS 1.1, 1.4, 1.6, 2.2, 2.5, 2.6 and 3.1)
Explain the principles of culturally responsive practice with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and communities (SPA PS 1.1, 1.4, 1.5, 1.6, 2.1, 2.2, 2.5, 2.6 and 3.1)
Explain the principles of cultural and linguistic responsiveness as relating to speech pathology practice (SPA PS 1.1, 1.4, 1.5, 1.6, 2.1, 2.2, 2.5, 2.6 and 3.1)
Describe the components of typical and disordered communication and swallowing in populations across the lifespan (SPA PS 1.1, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5, 1.6, 1.7, 2.5, 2.6, 3.1, 3.2, 3.3)
Use effective verbal and non-verbal communication and critical reflection skills across a variety of contexts in collaboration with peers (SPA PS 1.1, 1.5, 2.1, 2.2 and 2.6)

assessments.task_description:
This assessment focuses on the development of your reflective practice and lifelong learning skills, which underpins excellence in speech pathology practice.

Students are required to submit a Professional Practice Reflection Portfolio consisting of five (5) structured audio-visual recorded reflective tasks using the 5R Reflective Framework to facilitate the development of these skills. These reflections will be informed by the topics and learning objectives addressed within the SPCH7131 online learning activities and tutorials. Each reflection is due at 8am after the relevant learning activity. The first reflection is a formative reflection which will be marked and you will receive feedback. Each subsequent reflection is worth 5% (total 20%), with a limit of 2-3 minutes. 

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct

assessments.task_description:
This assessment allows students to demonstrate their ability to observe, interpret, and describe communication and swallowing in applied contexts.

Each group will be allocated a short video recording depicting a client who presents with a communication or swallowing disorder.

Your group will:

  1. Introduce the video - identify the client’s age, context, and purpose of the interaction.
  2. Discuss the aetiology of the communication or swallowing disorder.
  3. Describe the observable communication or swallowing behaviours evident in the video: (1) identify features of typical functioning for the person’s lifespan stage and (2) identify any characteristics consistent with disorder or difference.
  4. Compare typical and disordered features, explaining possible contributing factors (developmental, neurological, anatomical, environmental).
  5. Apply the ICF framework to the case, outlining: (1) body functions and structures involved, (2) activities and participation impacts and (3) environmental and personal factors influencing communication or swallowing
  6. Describe the role of the speech pathologist in supporting this individual, including potential assessment and management considerations.
  7. Demonstrate teamwork and clear communication throughout the presentation.

 

Each group will have 10 minutes to present followed by 2–3 minutes for questions. All group members must contribute equitably to the preparation and presentation.

learning_activities.topic:
Online pre-recorded lectures

In week 1 and 4, there are three online pre-recorded lectures designed for independent, self-paced learning. Each lecture takes approximately 2 hours to complete and provides and introduction to the course and foundational paediatric development knowledge.

learning_activities.topic:
Weekly On-Campus Tutorials

Tutorials will be held in person on campus during Weeks 1–3 and 5-8 of the semester. Each session will run for 2 hours and will incorporate small group discussions to explore key concepts in greater depth. These sessions are designed as experiential learning activities, and participants are expected to attend and actively engage. Occasionally, to prepare, students must complete pre-tutorial learning activities. As these sessions involve small group work, they will not be recorded.

learning_activities.topic:
In-Person Simulation Program

Students will participate in 4 x 4hour (9am-1pm) simulation-based learning workshops across both paediatric and adult areas of practice. In the paediatric module, students will develop their skills in information gathering and in the adult module, students will develop their skills in the assessment of communication and swallowing. Students will have the opportunity to interact with a variety of simulated patients (SPs) and Practice Educators (PEs) in order to develop their clinical reasoning and professional skills. Participation in these practical sessions is compulsory.
